message_1:
What is the standard enthalpy of formation of water (H2O) at 298 K, given the following balanced chemical equation and standard enthalpy of formation values?

2H2 (g) + O2 (g) → 2H2O (l) 

ΔHf° [H2 (g)] = 0 kJ/mol
ΔHf° [O2 (g)] = 0 kJ/mol
ΔHf° [H2O (l)] = -285.83 kJ/mol
message_2:
The standard enthalpy of formation (ΔHf°) of a compound is the change in enthalpy when 1 mole of the compound is formed from its elements in their standard states at a specified temperature, usually 298 K. In this case, we are given the standard enthalpy of formation for water (H2O) as -285.83 kJ/mol.

Since we are asked for the standard enthalpy of formation of water (H2O) at 298 K, and we are already given that value, the answer is:

ΔHf° [H2O (l)] = -285.83 kJ/mol
